Transcript: Marah: What are you doing here?
Catalina: This is my room.
Marah: This is my room. We're roommates.
Catalina: I'm not happy about this either.

Marah: This is ridiculous. When did you 
decide to go to school?

Catalina: I have a right to an education, 
Marah.

Marah: Oh, please. We both know why you're 
here.

Catalina: Yeah, to learn something, not just 
to party and meet boys.

Marah: Stuff it, Catalina. Speaking of stuff, 
are you always this messy? Speaking of stuff, you moved all my things.

Catalina: Well, I was trying to be polite. I 
thought my roommate was being polite by giving me the windows. I was going to 
give it to her... You.
Marah: Well, I hate sleeping by the window.

Catalina: Fine. We'll switch back. Sorry I 
tried to be nice.

Marah: Don't be so noble. Tony's not here to 
be impressed.

Catalina: You know, I wondered how long it 
would take you to mention him. Let's be honest, Marah. You don't like me because 
Tony does like me.

Marah: Oh, get over yourself. If you want 
Tony, take him. Oh, whoops, I forgot. You already did.

Catalina: You know, he's not a thing for you 
to give away. He's a very special person.
Marah: Wow. You got it bad.
Catalina: He's my friend.

Marah: I guess that means something different 
in Cuba.

Catalina: Yeah? Well, in Cuba and in 
Springfield, it's wrong to use a man, to string him along, and then break his 
heart.

Marah: Gee, when I filled out that 
questionnaire about what I wanted in a roommate, I don't think I checked off 
anything about stupid, unsolicited advice.

Catalina: Obviously this is not going to 
work.
Marah: Obviously.

Catalina: Well, I'm going to the student 
housing office and ask for a change.

Marah: So I end up with somebody that nobody 
wants? I don't think so. I'll go.
Catalina: Be my guest, Marah.
Marah: Hi.
Remy: Hey. I see you met your roommate. Good.
Marah: Yeah, not good.
Remy: Remy Boudreaux.
Catalina: Hi. Catalina Quesada.

Remy: I went through all this last year, so 
now I can pass off my hard-won knowledge to you entering freshman as your 
orientation coordinator. So, ladies, if you have any problems...
Catalina: Yeah, we do.
Marah: Yeah, we do.
Catalina: She's my problem.

Remy: All right. That's what I like to see in 
roomies: Unanimity of opinion. All right.
Marah: How do I go about changing roommates?

Remy: Okay. Well, you just go down to student 
housing and wait in line a couple of hours.
Marah: A couple of hours?

Remy: Right about now, about half your class 
is looking to change roommates, so... It's just those damn first impressions.
Catalina: We already know each other.

Remy: Well, that can be an advantage, you 
know? Kind of like knowing where your gear stick on your old corvette...? But if 
you insist...
Marah: Yes, we insist.
Catalina: I think it's best.

Remy: Well, hey, I understand. I had the same 
problem with my roommate freshman year.
Marah: And you got a new roommate?
Remy: Sure did. Last day of the semester.

Edmund: Of course, we'll have to dye your 
hair. Beth was a natural blonde.
Lorelei: Oh, so you mean all my hair?

Edmund: And that accent has to go. And that 
walk.

Lorelei: What's the matter with the way I 
walk?
Edmund: It's bumpy. Beth floated.
Lorelei: Well, good for her.

Edmund: Maybe I could show you some pictures 
of her. Perhaps a videotape, if I could get a hold of one. Now, listen, you'll 
have to know everything about Beth's children and her mother. Now, Beth had two 
ex-husbands. One's dead, which makes it a lot easier. There's no point in 
telling you any of this. What I need to do is get you to Springfield so you can 
see it for yourself. You can really soak up her world, get to understand her 
better. And we'll go today.

Lorelei: Now, hold on, now. I haven't agreed 
to this gig yet.
Edmund: But you said that we...
Lorelei: I said I think I can pull it off.
Edmund: And that you'd be my partner.

Lorelei: Well, let's hear the terms of the 
deal.

Edmund: Well, you impersonate my dead wife. I 
gain... Or rather, you gain control of her estate, hand it over to me, and then 
we leave Springfield on, I don't know, a 'round-the-world tour or something like 
that. We'll part ways in Malaysia, say, and you'll have a handsome salary and 
get into some exotic travel, and all of that.
Lorelei: And I get to be a princess?

Edmund: Well, technically speaking, for a 
time, at any rate.

Lorelei: That's the part I like. Princess 
Lorelei.
Edmund: No, princess Beth.

Lorelei: Wait until folks back home get a 
load of this. Why, Mrs. Powers in fourth grade said I'd never amount to 
anything. Well, kiss my crown, Mrs. Powers. I can't wait to see the look on her 
face.
Edmund: Wait. They can't know about this.
Lorelei: Well, why not?

Edmund: Well, for one reason, because it's 
illegal to impersonate someone. We'll land in jail. Or worse, I'll land back 
here in that god-awful tuxedo, hideously crooning ballads for convention 
delegates who don't tip.

Lorelei: Well, no one back home ever heard of 
San Cristo- whosis or whatever, anyhow, so what's the harm?

Edmund: And they're not going to hear about 
it from you. No one who knows Lorelei Hills can see you as Beth Winslow.
Lorelei: Not even my ma?

Edmund: No. I'm sorry, but that's the way it 
has to be.
Lorelei: Well, okay, then. Deal's off.

Michelle: How did she get released on bail? How does that happen? Who in their 
right minds would let her out on bail? I know that they gave her some electronic 
ankle bracelet, but this is a woman who's faked her death more than once. I just 
couldn't even sleep at all last night.

Danny: I'll tell you what. I'll file a 
restraining order today, okay?

Michelle: I think Carmen would take that as a 
challenge, don't you?
Danny: Yeah. Yeah, you're probably right.
Michelle: Do you have to get to work?

Danny: Yeah. (Cell phone ringing) in a 
little bit, yeah.
Michelle: You're not going to answer that?

Danny: Mm-mm. Can I have some more coffee? 
Can I have some coffee, please? Thanks.
Michelle: Why didn't you answer that?
Danny: It was a wrong number.

Michelle: (Laughs) How could you tell that 
it's a wrong number?
Danny: Because I don't recognize it.

Michelle: Yeah, but it could be somebody from 
work, right, with a... Calling from a different line?

Danny: Well, if it's important, then they'll 
leave a message.

Michelle: Then you should check your 
messages. Sorry.

Danny: You know, if you weren't so 
beautiful... We should do this more often, hmm?
Michelle: Yeah, but I kind of miss...
Danny: Have a date for breakfast.
Michelle: I miss the baby oatmeal in my hair.

Danny: (Laughs) You look a lot better 
without it.
Michelle: Thanks.

Danny: I just want to think about my 
beautiful, sexy wife who tastes like syrup.

Michelle: I know you don't want to think 
about that phone call.

Bernardo: Danny? Bernardo. Carlos asked me to call you with a friendly reminder. 
You have 12 hours before we have to tell them your decision. I'd hate to go 
upstairs with bad news.
Carmen: I like that, Bernardo. "Upstairs."

Bernardo: You said to keep your name out of 
it, but Danny knows someone is pulling the strings.

Carmen: I bet he's desperately trying to 
figure out who and why.

Bernardo: Or he's figuring how he can avoid 
stealing $25 million from Spaulding, which might lose him his nice suburban 
life.
Carmen: I know what Danny will do.
Bernardo: He's changed, Carmen.

Carmen: No, he hasn't. He's my son. A mother 
knows these things.
Danny: Hey.
Michelle: Mm-hmm?

Danny: No more distracting me with 
unimportant phone calls.
Michelle: Okay.
Danny: Okay?

Michelle: You know, as much as I love this, 
how long is it going to take you to get across town?

Danny: I don't know, ten minutes? Which 
should give me a few more minutes to tell my wife how gorgeous she is and how 
much I love her.

Michelle: Are we making a spectacle of 
ourselves?

Danny: Oh, who cares? Wait until you see what 
I've got planned for you tonight when I get home.

Michelle: You better hurry and get going so 
you can get home sooner. Ooh!

Danny: Good idea. All right. I'll call you 
later.
Michelle: Okay.
Danny: Okay?
Michelle: Thank you.

Danny: All right. I'll see you, sweetie. How 
am I going to get out of this?
Michelle: Oh. Uh-oh. Danny?
Catalina: So we may be stuck with each other?
Marah: Oh, great.

Remy: So Catalina, I, uh... I was reading 
your freshman bio. It says that you're originally from Cuba?
Catalina: Uh, yeah.
Remy: Cool, man. I always wanted to go there.
Catalina: Why?

Remy: I don't know. I mean, I have this image 
of Teddy Roosevelt charging up San Juan Hill and all that romantic island 
life... gambling, exotic nightclubs, topless beaches.
Catalina: Things have changed a lot.

Remy: Well, I guess you can give us the real 
scoop on that. Maybe you might want to do a dorm talk on it sometime.

Marah: Actually I'd really like to hear more 
about your music, Remy.
Catalina: You're A... You're a musician?
Remy: Are you?
Marah: No. But I sing.
Catalina: Karaoke.

Remy: My band's doing a couple of sets at the 
big back- to-campus bash tonight. Not to be missed.

Marah: Oh, I'd love to come but, you know, 
Catalina's not really into parties.

Catalina: I like to try everything about 
college.
Remy: All right, that's the spirit.

Marah: Well, she probably has to work, 
though.

Catalina: I work at Infierno. I'm the 
hostess. Do you know it?
Remy: Heard of it. I'll check it out.

Catalina: Yeah, well, if you come, I'll give 
you the best table in the house.

Remy: Oh, that means you can't make it 
tonight, then.

Catalina: Actually it's my night off. This 
party sounds like a whole lot of fun.

Sam: Marah, look. I got you a 
welcome-to-college freshman mascot gift.
Marah: Well, thanks.
Sam: Cat! What are you doing here?
Catalina: I'm an official freshman.

Sam: Congratulations, babe. Way to go. Good 
for you.

Edmund: Think of the experience. Think of the adventure. Think of the cold, hard 
cash.
Lorelei: You're very cold.
Edmund: And you're very stubborn.
Lorelei: Same difference.
Edmund: That's an oxymoron.

Lorelei: Hey, now you watch who you're 
calling moron. Okay, how about this: We slip into Albemarle and I try out the 
princess act-- in the house, just mom.
Edmund: Oh. No.
Lorelei: Well, that's it, then. No go.

Edmund: All right, then. Suit yourself. You 
know, I think I was wrong about you. You could never play Beth... Not 
convincingly, at any rate. Beth didn't have a cowardly bone in her body.
Bernardo: Naturally I'm happy to assist you in this.

Carmen: Come on, Bernardo. Who are we 
kidding? You'd love to see me in prison for the rest of my life. All the more to 
divide among the rest of you-- you, Johnny, and Carlos.
Bernardo: Oh, come on, now, Carmen.

Carmen: But I've never known you to turn down 
a hefty payoff.
Bernardo: For services rendered.

Carmen: Exactly. You set Danny up; I take him 
down.
Bernardo: I assume the reason...
Carmen: Never assume.

Bernardo: Your goal, then? It's Danny's wife, 
isn't it? Understandable, after what she did to poor Mick. Now she's turned 
Danny into a useless nobody.
Carmen: No, not useless. Not at all.

Bernardo: But your grandson. Doesn't this put 
the child at risk? I mean, if Danny were to be caught...?
Carmen: When Danny is caught.
Bernardo: How?

Carmen: The fewer details you know, the 
better, my friend. You will profit handsomely from this. Don't you worry about 
my grandson. You leave that up to me.
Tony: Aunt Carmen.
Carmen: Antonio.

Tony: They let you out. I'm surprised they 
didn't lock you up and throw away the key.

Carmen: Yes, well they did. But that's 
because y don't know me very well. Maybe we should do something about that, huh?
Danny: Okay, that was too easy.

Phillip: Danny, some people that I would like 
you to talk to... What the hell are you doing?
Phillip: Danny?
Danny: What?

Phillip: Who authorized you to access my 
father's personal account?
Danny: No one.

Phillip: So you just broke in to his 
financial files?
Danny: Yeah, that's right.
Phillip: And you just freely admit that?

Danny: Yeah. I'm writing up a full report on 
that.
Phillip: A report?

Danny: Yeah. It turns out that Spaulding is a 
hell of a lot more vulnerable than I ever suspected. Originally I thought we 
were just going to have to shore up the internal systems-- you know, encryption, 
software, stuff like that. But now we're going to need a whole new system of 
failsafe internal security measures. I'm thinking we're going to need infrared 
sensors on the doors that are leading to the sensitive computers, laser beams in 
all the areas that have access to the computers. These computers are the heart 
and soul of Spaulding, and the way it is now, anybody could walk in off the 
street and break in. It's unacceptable.

Phillip: Hmm. And I suppose that you would 
probably want to oversee the installation of all this equipment. That way, you 
would know exactly how it works or it might be vulnerable.
Danny: Well, yeah, it's my job.
Phillip: Your job seems to be expanding.

Danny: If you got a problem with that, you 
should talk to your father about it.
Phillip: Danny?
Danny: Hmm?

Phillip: Don't underestimate my father. 
Better men than you have made that mistake and regretted it.
Danny: Are you one of those people?

Phillip: Whatever it is you're working on, 
let's leave my father's personal bank account out of it.

Danny: Don't you think that should be up to 
Alan?

Phillip: Alan? Alan? I think that's still 
"Mr. Spaulding" to you. Come with me.
Danny: Where to?

Phillip: Personnel have some security 
questions that you need to answer. (Laughter)
Tory: Excuse me, professor.
Ross: Oh, hi.
Tory: Do you mind if I sit?

Ross: No, no, no. Go ahead, be my guest. 
Unless, of course, you want to sit with the young people. I'm pretty much a 
chaperone over here, complete with my briefcase and my lawyer clothes.
Tory: But that's what you are: A lawyer.
Ross: And how.
Tory: Are you ashamed of that?
Danny: Hey.

Michelle: I think you missed an important 
call.
Lorelei: Nobody calls me a coward.

Edmund: You're throwing away the chance of a 
lifetime just because your mother can't know about it? Oh, come off it. You're 
hiding. You're scared you won't be able to cut the mustard, and that you'll 
fail, and you're just finding an excuse to run away.
Lorelei: Well, that's a lousy thing to say.

Edmund: That's a lousy thing to do. Ah, maybe 
it's just because you don't think you have it in you to play someone like Beth.

Lorelei: I'll have you know I've done a 
little acting in my time. In fact, I played Annie in "Annie get your gun," and I 
was great.
Edmund: Where?
Lorelei: High school.

Edmund: Wow. Face it. You're out of your 
league.
Lorelei: Says who?

Edmund: Says me. Think about what I'm 
offering you here. Think about it. No... Nothing attached to it. Just a few 
rules. Oh, come on. What are your options, huh? What are they? Welfare? A 
shelter? You'll probably starve to death first.
Lorelei: Hey, hey. I have options, okay?

Edmund: Yes, and you throwing one of them 
away right now. And why? Because it involves a little risk? No, no, no. You'd 
rather hide. You'd rather hide from life. You'd rather hide from yourself. Yes, 
yes. I can see it now. No, you're nothing like my... Nothing like my wife. Now, 
Beth, Beth was fearless. Life would knock her down; she'd get right back up 
again. It never made her hardhearted. She was the most tender woman I've ever 
known in my life. She was gentle, she was loving, but strong and brave. Brave. 
Brave, that's what I need. I need someone who's brave to do this. I can see that 
now. You won't do at all. No. I'm sorry I took up your time, Lorelei Hills.

Lorelei: Now, you wait just a darn minute. 
You don't know me.
Edmund: No, I know you're not Beth.

Lorelei: I can be Beth. I can be Beth with my 
hands tied behind my back.
Edmund: No, you can't.
Lorelei: Okay, you got your woman, Eddie.
Edmund: Oh, is that so?

Lorelei: You want heart? I got heart in 
spades. You want courage? That's me. Anything your Beth could do, I can do 
better.
Edmund: Show me.
Lorelei: I ain't afraid of anything.
Edmund: Words are cheap.

Lorelei: Well, bring it on. I can pull this 
off with my eyes shut.

Edmund: What a shame that would be. You have 
such beautiful eyes.
Lorelei: One thing we gotta be clear about.
Edmund: The money?
Lorelei: That, too. This is more important.
Edmund: More important than money?

Lorelei: I'll play your wife, but I won't be 
your wife, know what I mean? Sex is out. This is strictly business.
Edmund: Strictly business.

Lorelei: And another thing. As soon as we get 
hold of your wife's estate, we get a nice, friendly divorce.
Edmund: I don't want to divorce Beth.
Lorelei: Well, tough. Those are my rules.
Edmund: Fine.

Lorelei: And I get a third of anything you 
pick up from this deal.
Edmund: A third? Right, a third it is.

Lorelei: Well, it looks like we got ourselves 
a deal.

Edmund: Well, in that case, I have work to 
do.
Lorelei: Where are you going?

Edmund: I'm going to round up enough cash to 
get us to Springfield.
Lorelei: How?
Edmund: Well, I have unseen talents.
Lorelei: Yeah, lounge singing.

Edmund: When I come back here, which will be 
very soon, I'll have more money than we need, I assure you. 

Lorelei: Oh, Eddie, you need to get yourself a keeper.
Catalina: Well, actually, Marah and I are roommates.
Sam: Really?
Marah: Yeah.
Sam: Wow. Okay, cool.

Remy: Well, I've got 20 more freshmen to meet 
and greet, so I'll see you tonight. You're welcome too, Sam.
Sam: Thanks. Welcome to what?
Marah: The party you're going to take me to.
Sam: Party? Oh, really?

Marah: Yes. Just because you're taking a year 
off school doesn't mean that we can't date, does it?
Sam: This is a date?
Marah: Well, yeah.

Catalina: Sam, why are you taking a year off 
school?

Sam: I thought it would be a good idea. I 
mean, I don't know. We'll see. I might still audit some classes, though, you 
know? Keep my hand in it.

Marah: So, are you going to come to the party 
with me?

Sam: Well, it's this whole date thing that's 
kind of throwing me here.
Marah: Of course it's a date.

Sam: All right, you are my witness. I am 
officially dating Marah Lewis, college freshman. (Clapping)
Tony: Congratulations.
Danny: I was wondering where I left that. Thanks.
Michelle: Not so fast.

Danny: Cute. But honey, I don't really have 
time for games. Phillip just dumped an extra assignment on me for personnel 
security. I think he wants to work me so hard that I'll never see the light of 
day. I'm not even sure what time I'll make it home tonight.

Michelle: Cut it out, Danny. I played back 
the message that you were so anxious not to hear this morning at company.
Danny: Since when do you spy on me?

Michelle: Since you get a message from 
Bernardo Sandoval saying you have 12 hours to give them your decision. What is 
it you have to decide?
Marah: Tony, hi.
Sam: Hi, Tony.
Tony: How's it going?

Catalina: Interesting. Marah and I are 
roommates.

Tony: Well, I wonder how long that's going to 
last for?

Marah: I'm sure we'll get along okay. Well, I 
guess you came here to see Catalina, so Sam and I will give you some privacy.
Sam: Right. See you, guys.

Marah: I bet she invited him over here just 
to rub it in my face.

Sam: The same way you invited me to the party 
tonight to rub it in Tony's face?
Marah: Did I ask you in front of him?

Sam: No. But you knew Catalina would report 
back.

Marah: So? I really want to go with you. Why 
wouldn't I? You're fun and sexy, and you're the one person I can count on, and 
look at what you did for my dad when he got accused of bribing.
Sam: I didn't do anything.

Marah: Would you just stop? Stop being so 
modest. You got the original picture that showed that that mobster gave the bag 
of cash to Mr. Vreeland. You're a real friend, Sam.

Sam: You don't have to twist my arm any more 
than that. You know I want to take you to this thing tonight.
Tony: So this is what college is like, huh?

Catalina: No. No, this is just where I sleep. 
It's not that different from the boarding house. But the classes, the classes. 
That's what really excites me.

Tony: You're going to be so smart, I won't 
know what to talk to you about.
Catalina: You know, you could go to college.

Tony: I'm allergic to school. But I'm happy 
for you.

Catalina: Thanks. But there's something that 
I think you should know. Your grandmother, she pulled some strings to get me in 
here. Got me a scholarship.
Tony: She did this?

Catalina: Yeah, but I don't want to be in 
debt to her, or to anyone, Tony.

Tony: Don't worry about it. Look, you would 
have gotten that scholarship anyway, right? Trust me.
Catalina: I just hope I fit in here.
Tony: Don't let Marah do a number on you.
Catalina: Like the one she did on you?

Tony: You know, you are going to make so many 
friends here. You're going to be, like, scoring straight A's and elected class 
president and...
Catalina: That's enough, enough, enough.

Tony: You know, you probably won't have 
enough time to spend with me.

Catalina: I'll always have time for you, 
Tony-- especially you. In fact, I need your help, but I don't want to put you in 
an awkward situation.

Ross: No, Miss Granger, I'm not ashamed of being a lawyer. It's just, lately I 
have been reevaluating what it means to me.

Tory: And teaching a class on the subject is 
part of that process.

Ross: I'd have to say it is, yes. I'm sorry. 
May I confess something to you?
Tory: Well, there is a lawyer present.

Ross: Well, in spite of that, I'm known as 
being fairly smooth and feeling fairly comfortable in a courtroom. But I felt 
exceedingly awkward the other day in the classroom.

Tory: When you assumed that my husband had 
divorced me instead of predeceased me.

Ross: That was certainly part of it, yes. 
Forgive me for that.

Tory: Ditto. It was a logical conclusion 
really, but I made you feel awful about it, and I shouldn't have.

Ross: You're very motivated by him, aren't 
you? If you don't mind talking about it, how did he die?

Tory: Stu was killed by a drunk driver. And 
the idiot who tanked up on cheap beer and then just snuffed out a wonderful man 
and a brilliant legal mind, he got off scot-free. Stu was my inspiration, not 
just my husband. He would have had an amazing career, and I would have had him. 
But now all of that is gone, so I decided to pick up where he left off.
Ross: By going into law yourself.

Tory: By being as brilliant as he would have 
been. That's another reason why I gave you such a hard time in class the other 
day. I didn't want you to waste my time.
Ross: Did I pass the audition?

Tory: Yes. Being every bit the lawyer that he 
would have been is the only thing that I'll settle for, and if a class can't 
take me where I need to go, then I go.

Ross: That's a very direct approach. But Miss 
Granger, I believe that you have blurred the line between teacher and student.
Tory: How do you mean?

Ross: Well, you are instructing me as to how 
to conduct to this class by telling me how everyone, particularly yourself, 
should get something of value out of this course.

Tory: Well, I realize that our legal system 
is adversarial, but does that mean that the teaching of it has to be? I think we 
should all get something out of this, and help each other. Don't you?
Ross: If you say so.
Tory: I do.
Danny: What is this, 20 questions?

Michelle: No, it's one question. One 
question. What is it Bernardo wants you to do?
Danny: Don't worry about it.

Michelle: If you feel that you can't tell me, 
then I am worried. 12 hours to decide what?

Danny: 12 hours to decide whether or not I'm 
going to sell Infierno to Bernardo, all right?
Michelle: And why would you do that?

Danny: Because I'm going to sell the club, 
and Tony doesn't have the money. No bank is going to give him a loan. And if he 
gets the money from the other families, then they will own him, body and soul. 
This way, if I sell it to Bernard, it's out of everybody's hands.

Michelle: Now why don't you tell me what's 
really going on. Because on the message, Bernardo said he didn't want to have to 
go upstairs with bad news. Now, that doesn't sound like Infierno, does it? So 
you're lying to me? Is this the kind of marriage that you want? Because it's not 
what I signed up for, not by a long shot.
Tony: If you need my help, all you have to do is ask.

Catalina: Okay. You know that party that 
Marah mentioned? Do you maybe want to go with me?

Tony: Um, the whole college thing, you 
know... I'm not into that scene.
Catalina: Okay. I won't go either.
Tony: You want to go.
Catalina: Not alone.
Tony: You'll make friends.

Catalina: I have a friend: You. But it's 
okay, it's okay. I'll just go to the library or something.

Tony: No, no, no. Come here. No, no, no. Once 
you get there, you're going to be like, bam, you know? You're going to be, like, 
super popular. Everybody's going to be going over themselves trying to meet you.

Catalina: Yeah, well, I wish I had your 
confidence in me. Maybe I would if you were there. Please, please? Just this 
once?
Tony: You're going to regret it.

Catalina: I won't, I won't. Thank you. Thank 
you so much.
Tony: All right.
Marah: Oops, sorry. Next time I'll knock.

Catalina: Well, it looks like we're all going 
to the party. Isn't that great?
Marah: Yeah, terrific.
Sam: Well, it'll make my night.

Marah: I think I can come up with a way to 
make it even better.

Alan: You do understand, don't you, why... why you can't admit that Danny's a 
wonderful find.
Phillip: Because I'm a smart guy.

Alan: Because you can't admit that your old 
man was right and you were wrong.

Phillip: Well, god knows you love being 
right. I thought I was bad about that, but I am nothing compared to you. You're 
like a kid, you know that? You really are. You're like a kid. You have to win 
all the time.

Alan: Well, I'm going to take that as a 
compliment, because I'm telling you something. These past few days, I'm feeling 
ageless.
Phillip: Gee, I wonder why. How is Olivia?

Alan: You know, there's nothing like 
stimulating female companionship, something that's sorely been missing in your 
life, Phillip, especially since Beth's been gone.

Phillip: Don't do me any favors. I've got my 
hands full taking care of the kids.

Alan: I know you have. I'm glad you're there 
for them, to influence them and guide them. How is Beth's estate coming along? 
Do you need any help with that?

Phillip: No. I think it's going to be pretty 
straightforward, although I'm going to have to have her declared legally dead, 
since we didn't find a body in Mexico.

Alan: Well don't let it drag out, because I 
don't trust Edmund Winslow. He's like a bad penny that turns up again and again.

Phillip: Doesn't matter. He can't hurt her 
anymore. That's the only good thing, is that's she's finally at peace.

Gambler: That does it for me. I'll join the rest of them at the bar next door, 
not that she left us with any money for drinks.

Night manager: You cleaned me out too, 
Lorelei. Word of advice: Don't bet any more than you want to lose.
Edmund: What were the stakes?
Lorelei: How'd you do?
Edmund: Oh, about the same.
Lorelei: Yeah? Well, let's see it, then.

Edmund: I transferred all the money into my 
account in Springfield.
Lorelei: Sure you did. Sure you did, Eddie.

Edmund: You know, I was right. You may look a 
great deal like Beth, but the similarity ends there.

Lorelei: Well, Springfield, here we come. 
Well, come on now, Eddie. Let's get a move on.

Danny: You know that the only reason I would ever lie to you would be to protect 
you and Robbie.

Michelle: And it's always backfired. Danny, 
the only right way for us is to share everything. And that means good and bad. 
If we can't do that, then it's not a marriage. Please, don't shut me out.

Danny: All right. Okay. Okay. That's a 
scrambler, in case anybody's listening.

Michelle: You think that Alan's bugged your 
office?

Danny: He might, and so would some other 
people.
Michelle: "Upstairs"?

Danny: Yeah. The other families want me back 
in, and I don't see any way out.
